awd_titl_txt: SCH: INT: Collaborative Research: Smart Wearable Systems to Support and Measure Movement in Children With and Without Mobility Impairments
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on the development of wearable technologies to measure and assist upper-limb mobility in children with mobility impairments. Because mobility impairments in early life can have long-term effects on psychological as well as physical development, it is important both to help children overcome these impairments through assistive technologies and to be able to measure the effect of interventions in everyday movements over long periods of time. However, most assistive and sensing technologies are bulky and uncomfortable. The project team will develop soft, low-profile sensing and actuating technologies that look and feel like everyday clothing. The wearable systems will be developed and evaluated with a group of 3-12 year old children and their caregivers. This work will contribute to the development of technologies that enable understanding and effects of interventions on mobility impairments, and contribute to the burgeoning smart textiles and clothing industry in the USA.  


The approach relies on stitched, textile-based sensing and a hybrid approach of soft inflatable structures and shape-memory fibers to assist limb movements. Learning based activity recognition algorithms will be developed that are robust to differences in body shape and garment-movement error. The atypical movements performed by children with mobility impairments will be recognized, enabling assessment of clinical indicators like range of movement. The actuating component of the proposed system uses soft pneumatic structures to provide counter-gravitational (lift) forces, and Shape Memory Alloy (SMA) spring-type actuators to provide directional control. The system will be developed in two phases: initially, the sensing component and the passive lift (inflatable abduction support) will be developed using typically-developing children, and tested in 4-week in-home trials with 15 children with mobility impairments. The active actuated system will be developed and deployed in collaboration with 5-10 families with children with mobility impairments over a period of one year. The effects of both systems on user?s upper-limb mobility as well as the usability and social acceptability of the systems will be evaluated.

por.por_cntn:
This project was a collaboration between the University of Minnesota (apparel design), University of Delaware (physical therapy), and Virginia Tech (electrical and computer engineering). The major goals of the overall project were to:

1) Develop and validate a clinical pediatric mobility monitoring system for the upper limbs, and provide a formative evaluation of a wearable exoskeleton with pneumatic assist

2) Develop and validate of a closed-loop, user-controllable active mobility-support soft exoskeleton

The main focus of Virginia Tech?s portion of the research project was to estimate joint angles for the shoulder and elbow based using a stitch-based textile stretch sensor developed by the University of Minnesota in prior research. The stitch-based sensor changed its electrical resistance in response to bending and stretching of the textile. To develop and evaluate the joint angle estimation, the team collected human motion data simultaneously using an optical motion capture system and a prototype garment with several of the sensors stitched on the shoulder and elbow of the garment. The sensor was also characterized for its electrical behavior in response to be elongated and relaxed parallel to the surface of the textile, as well as in response to be compressed perpendicularly to the surface of the textile.  The joint angles were estimated from the stitch-based sensors output by solving an optimization problem based upon minimizing the error between the expected and actual outputs of the sensors at a given time. This optimization approach was experimentally shown to have an average error of about 2 degrees in estimating the elbow joint angle and about 4 degrees for estimating the shoulder joint angle. Additional research is needed to improve the accuracy of the approach by better understanding and accounting for the non-ideal characteristics of the stitch-based sensors.

A broader outcome is that, if the stitched sensors can be made to more accurately estimate joint angles, the stitched sensors would overcome several of the shortcomings of inertial measurement unit (IMU)-based wearable motion capture systems. For example, the magnetometers in the IMUs are affected by changes in the magnetic field around the person, while the accelerometers are affected by integration drift over time. The stitched angle sensors would overcome those shortcomings while having the added benefit of being more effectively integrated into apparel, making them more wearable and users more compliant to their use. Furthermore, wearable technology that looks and feels like normal, everyday clothing has the potential to have impacts on a wide range of application areas, from medicine (e.g., ambulatory medical monitoring) to biomechanics (e.g., in situ motion capture measurements) to construction and manufacturing (e.g., personal protective equipment that provides individualized warnings and alerts) to entertainment (e.g., fully immersive gaming). The work performed on this project will inform the design and development of next generation smart garments, such that they have the potential to more easily fit into a person's daily routine, thus leading to greater acceptance and more widespread use.
